introduction:
Huatao is a postdoctoral researcher at The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, advised by Prof. Mo Li. He obtained Ph.D. degree from Nanyang Technological University, supervised by Prof. Mo Li and co-supervised by Prof. Rui Tan. Before that, he received B.S. degree from Nanjing University and Master's degree from Shanghai Jiao Tong University.

He is broadly interested in ubiquitous computing, especially in related fields of building wearable-based or wireless-based sensing interfaces to bridge gaps between computing resources and human's daily lives. His current research focuses on wearable-based sensing, including human activity recognition, localization, authentication, etc.

project.intro: This project investigates the potential of large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT, to process IoT sensor data and accomplish tasks in the physical world, extending their capabilities beyond natural language processing. We term this endeavor Penetrative AI -- where the embedded world knowledge in LLMs serves as a foundation, seamlessly integrated with the Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) for perceiving and intervening in the physical world.

publication.title: Penetrative AI

project.name: Human Activity Recognition
project.intro: This project proposes a universal learning framework for mobile devices that employs physics-informed data augmentation techniques and IMU foundation models to address data heterogeneity in IMU-based HAR.

publication.title: UniHAR

project.name: Sensor Foundation Model
project.intro: This project targets designing foundation models for sensor data. We present a BERT-like self-supervised representation learning for IMU data, which extracts generalized features from abundant unlabeled sensor data and substantially reduces the supervised training overhead for down-stream task-specific sensing models.

publication.title: LIMU-BERT

project.name: mmRadar-based Gesture Recognition
project.intro: Our research project aims at leveraging self-supervised learning to enhance millimeter-wave radar-based gesture recognition, addressing the challenge of overfitting due to scarce high-quality labeled data. We introduce RadarAE, a novel representation learning framework that utilizes unlabeled radar data to improve gesture recognition accuracy in few-shot learning scenarios.

publication.title: RadarAE

project.name: RFID-based Localization
project.intro: Our research project focuses on the intricacies of RFID signal characteristics to develop a precise indoor localization system for RFID tags. We introduce an innovative approach named Deep Learning Enhanced Holography (DLEH), which integrates RFID-based Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to create a dynamic and adaptive localization model. Additionally, this project explores the integration of compressive sensing algorithms into RFID localization, further enhancing its efficiency and accuracy.
